title: Our Gary : Did Lineker Defeat united kingdom Government War on Migrants ?
body_text:
Swansea City fans support of Gary Lineker after his suspension by the BBC, March 11, 2023 (Bradley Collyer/PA)
Co-published with the Centre for Brexit Studies
:
In the final scene of the 1991 play A Night With Gary Lineker, the football player descends from the heavens to the sound of Luciano Pavorottiâ€™s Nessun Dorma. He hovers in a radiant glow, offering hope to three lovelorn, life-torn Britons on holiday.
â€œDo your farts really smell of perfume?â€ asks Monica.
The footballer proves they do. Fulfilling their â€” and our â€” dreams, he smiles and ascends.
But it is 2023. And a post-Brexit UK Government has no tolerance for such dreams, especially if they are the dreams of migrants or asylum seekers.
Braverman Attacks
The Government should have been enjoying a rare moment of triumph. On February 27, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and the European Unionâ€™s Ursula von der Leyen announced the â€œWindsor Agreementâ€ to bolster Northern Ireland Protocol, ending years of tension over the post-Brexit status of the Irish island.
See also Brexitâ€™s Broken Britain and the Northern Ireland Protocol
But even as Sunak and Von der Leyen were speaking, Home Secretary Suella Braverman was tweeting that migrants were murderers who should be deported to Rwanda immediately. Three days later, her office declared that the â€œIllegal Migration Billâ€ would stop anyone â€” migrants, asylum seekers, refugees â€” trying to reach the UK in small boats crossing the English Channel.
A â€œsourceâ€ hijacked the Windsor Agreement for the initiative, telling right-wing tabloids, â€œThere is now a political imperative to seize upon the opportunities that have been provided by the Northern Ireland Protocolâ€.
Braverman went further in an interview with the right-wing attack outlet GB â€œNewsâ€, pledging that anyone who did make it to the UK would be sent to Rwanda: â€œIf you arrive in the UK illegally, you will be detained and youâ€™ll be swiftly removed.â€
At a constituency meeting, an 83-year-old Holocaust survivor, Joan Salter, asked Braverman to refrain from terms like â€œswarmsâ€ and â€œinvasionâ€ dehumanizing the migrants. Salter noted that the language was similar to that used in Germany in the 1930s against groups inside and outside the country.
Braverman responded, â€œI wonâ€™t apologise for the language that I have used to demonstrate the scale of the problemâ€¦.We have a problem with people exploiting our generosity, breaking our laws and undermining our system.â€
â€œOur Garyâ€ Intervenesâ€¦and the Government Goes To War With Culture
Like her predecessor Priti Patel, Braverman is eagerly using migrants and asylum seekers as the punching bag for her political ambition. But far from restraining the Home Secretary, Prime Minister Sunak has enabled the attacks. The Illegal Immigration Bill was tabled in Parliament on March 7, with Braverman proclaiming that â€œ100 millionâ€ asylum seekers could come to the UK if she relented.
The Bill threatened to violate international humanitarian law, including the 1951 Refugee Convention. Braverman privately admitted to Conservatives that her measures were â€œmore than 50% likelyâ€ to be in breach. But publicly she told Sky News, â€œWeâ€™ve made it very clear that we believe weâ€™re in compliance with all of our international obligations.â€
Then she went back on the attack: â€œThey are breaking our laws, they are abusing the generosity of the British people and we now need to ensure that they are deterred from doing that.â€
At 2:25 p.m. on March 7, Gary Lineker tweeted:
There is no huge influx. We take far fewer refugees than other major European countries. This is just an immeasurably cruel policy directed at the most vulnerable people in language that is not dissimilar to that used by Germany in the 30s, and Iâ€™m out of order?
â€” Gary Lineker ğŸ’™ğŸ’› (@GaryLineker) March 7, 2023
Lineker was only saying pointedly what Jean Salter and others observed about Bravermanâ€™s rhetoric. Professor Tanja Bueltmann, a historian at Strathclyde University, summarized:
Hi @BBC,
As a German I can tell you this: when politicians speak in a language not dissimilar to that used in 1930s Germany, I recognise it. Why? Because I have been taught about it all my lifeâ€”and that it needs to be called out and rejected. Itâ€™s a duty to do so, in fact. ğŸ§µ https://t.co/l9SoW1Cdyjâ€” Prof Tanja Bueltmann (@TanjaBueltmann) March 8, 2023
But Braverman and her Cabinet colleagues saw an opportunity for success beyond the tarnishing of migrants.
At the end of February, â€œLevelling Upâ€ Secretary Michael Gove told a gathering, labelled The Future of Conservatism, that success could come from confronting â€œthe radical leftâ€ and â€œradical social transformationâ€.
He proclaimed, â€œTheir world is divided into those who bear original sin â€“ whether whiteness or some other privilege â€“ and those whose suffering, linked indissolubly to their identity, gives them the moral authority to re-order this fallen world.â€
In the guise of â€œbringing peace to our cultural warâ€, the Government â€” and eager right-wing outlets â€” could profit from waging war on cultural figures.
And so, on the morning of March 8, Braverman said she was â€œvery disappointedâ€ in Linekerâ€™s irresponsible tweet. Asked if he should be sacked after presenting the BBCâ€™s flagship football program Match of the Day since 1999, the Home Secretary dog-whistled, â€œThatâ€™s a matter for the BBC and they will resolve that.â€
The Conservative Partyâ€™s deputy chairman Lee Anderson followed up, â€œThis is just another example of how out of touch these overpaid stars are with the voting public. Instead of lecturing, Mr Lineker should stick to reading out the football scores and flogging crisps.â€
The right-wing tabloids piled on. â€œItâ€™s Time to Show Preening, Ignorant Poseur Gary Lineker The Exit Door,â€ screeched the Daily Mail. GB â€œNewsâ€ featured Conservative MP Andrea Jenkyns decreeing, â€œIf the BBC doesnâ€™t fire Gary Lineker, we should DEFUND them!â€
Even if the BBC had a clear policy on social media posts by employees, Lineker â€” as a freelance presenter rather than a full-time staff member â€” was not bound by it. But BBC chairman Richard Sharp was a prominent Conservative donor who brokered an Â£800,000 loan to Boris Johnson during his tenure as Prime Minister. Another board member, Robbie Gibb â€” ardent Brexiter and former communications director for Theresa May â€” has been described by former BBC Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis as an â€œactive Tory agentâ€ inside the Corporation. BBC Director-General Tim Davie had told staff to avoid â€œvirtue signallingâ€ and directed them not to attend â€œpublic demonstrations or gatherings about controversial issuesâ€.
On Friday, March 10, Lineker was suspended from presenting Match of the Day the following evening.
But Then The Cultural Twist
But Braverman, the Government, and the BBC executives had miscalculated.
Over the next 24 hours, Linekerâ€™s colleagues took a stand alongside him. Match of the Day analysts Ian Wright and Alan Shearer refused to appear, with Wright emphasizing, â€œIf the BBC get rid of Gary Lineker, Iâ€™m out. Iâ€™m gone.â€ Rising presenter Alex Scott, a former standout with the England womenâ€™s football team, said she would not host Football Focus. Other match commentators and analysts followed.
By Saturday night, Match of the Day had been reduced to a 20-minute program stripped of commentary, analysis, and any other accompaniment apart from a humming of crowd noise. Even the iconic MOTD theme tune was gone.
Perhaps more importantly, the public had not rallied to the War on Culture. Far from brandishing pitchforks, they embraced Lineker. A typical post chided the BBC, â€œI think youâ€™ve lost touch with your audience, your country, and reality, if you think messing with MOTD and Gary Lineker is going to go well for you.â€ Another explained, â€œThe BBC is a public broadcaster. This isnâ€™t Russia, Iran, or China. Not yet anyway.â€
Recognizing the Governmentâ€™s mis-step, the Daily Mail jumped ship: â€œGary Lineker IS Match of the Day, Thereâ€™s No Point Watching Nowâ€™.â€
In the War on Culture, the Government had failed to comprehend English culture. This was not any â€œwokeâ€ activist or a comrade of Michael Goveâ€™s caricature â€œRadical Leftâ€. This was Gary Lineker â€” 48 goals in 80 England appearances, the leader who almost brought home the 1990 World Cup, the Saturday night fixture in living rooms across the country for 24 years.
Ministers could brandish the English flag to agitate for Brexit and then cover up its failures. They could brandish the flag to warn that â€œothersâ€ â€” the migrants, the asylum seekers, the refugees â€” would overrun â€œEnglandâ€. But they had tried to brandish it against a man bound up with the Three Lions and that flag.
On Monday, March 12, Director General Davie gave way. Lineker was reinstated, with a note that rules on social media impartiality would be reviewed.
Lineker tweeted, just before his return to Match of the Day the following Saturday, â€œAh, the joys of being allowed to stick to football.â€
But he had quietly changed the avatar on his Twitter account. He was standing, in front of Broadcasting House, alongside the George Orwell statue and quote, â€œIf liberty means anything at all, it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear.â€
A Pause Of The Toxic
Of course, Linekerâ€™s victory does not mean that the Government has given up its War on Migrants.
Trying to regain the initiative, Braverman spent taxpayer money on a flight to Rwanda where she insisted that â€œthis world-leading partnershipâ€ â€” with a country accused of systematic human rights violations â€” â€œis both humanitarian and compassionate and also fair and balancedâ€.
A Home Office official said that the first migrants and asylum seekers would finally be deported: â€œWe are certainly working towards getting the flights off before the summer.â€
Cabinet Minister Oliver Dowden tried to portray the Government as the victim. â€œWe are being forced to do it,â€ he insisted. The Daily Mail had regained its enthusiasm: â€œCan Braverman The Builder Fix Immigration System?â€
Meanwhile, the Refugee Council estimated that, under the Illegal Migration Bill, more than 250,000 people â€” including up to 45,000 children â€” could have their asylum claims deemed inadmissible in the three years after the measure was implemented. The cost of detaining and accommodating them could be more than Â£9 billion.
For a moment, as in the happy ending in the 1991 play, the perfume of Gary Lineker had swept through England.
But all too soon, the toxic stench of a Government bent on waging its war â€” on migrants, on asylum seekers, and on a culture that might prefer decency and tolerance over xenophobia â€” may return.
